name: BodyBuilder

unions.name: FlexItem
unions.comment:
The type of the flex items. A flex container contains only specific items.
Those are represented by this type. They're generated by the flexItem function,
to be used exclusively in flex.

unions.name: GridItem
unions.comment:
The type of the grid items. A grid container contains only specific items.
Those are represented by this type. They're generated by the gridItem function,
to be used exclusively in grid.

unions.name: Option
unions.comment:
Represents the different options used in select items. They're generated by
the option function, exclusively to be used in select.

aliases.name: BlockAttributes
aliases.comment:
Represents the attributes for a block element, i.e. an element which can't be
anything else other than a block. This includes titles, paragraph, section, nav,
article, aside, footer, header and div. This element have to use `Style.blockProperties`
to set style on them.
aliases.type: BodyBuilder.Attributes.HeadingAttributes msg

aliases.name: Document
aliases.comment: Document, like in Browser, but for BodyBuilder.
aliases.type: { title : String.String, body : BodyBuilder.NodeWithStyle msg }

aliases.name: Node
aliases.comment:
The main type of BodyBuilder. It is an alias to Html, in order to keep
perfect backward compatibility.
aliases.type: Html.Html msg

aliases.name: NodeWithStyle
aliases.comment:
NodeWithStyle is allowing BodyBuilder to have Nodes with styles inside them.
It is the central type of Bodybuilder, and inside that type resides the key asset of
BodyBuilder and Elegant
aliases.type: ( BodyBuilder.Node msg, List.List String.String )

values.name: a
values.comment:
Generates a link in the DOM. A link is inline by default, but
changes its behavior when specifically set as block. You don't have to worry about
the display: use an a whenever you want, style like you want, it will adapt to
what you wrote.

    inlineLink : NodeWithStyle msg
    inlineLink =
        -- This produces an inline a in the DOM.
        BodyBuilder.a [] []

    blockLink : NodeWithStyle msg
    blockLink =
        -- This produces a block a in the DOM.
        BodyBuilder.a [ BodyBuilder.Attributes.style [ Style.block [] ] ] []
values.type: Modifiers.Modifiers (BodyBuilder.Attributes.AAttributes msg) -> List.List (BodyBuilder.NodeWithStyle msg) -> BodyBuilder.NodeWithStyle msg

values.name: application
values.comment: Creates a program, like you could with Html.
values.type: { init : flags -> Url.Url -> Browser.Navigation.Key -> ( model, Platform.Cmd.Cmd msg ), view : model -> BodyBuilder.Document msg, update : msg -> model -> ( model, Platform.Cmd.Cmd msg ), subscriptions : model -> Platform.Sub.Sub msg, onUrlRequest : Browser.UrlRequest -> msg, onUrlChange : Url.Url -> msg } -> Platform.Program flags model msg

values.name: flexItem
values.comment:
Generates a flexItem in the DOM. A flexItem is only used inside flex, and
can contains the specific styling of the flexChildren.

        BodyBuilder.flex []
            [ BodyBuilder.flexItem []
                [ Html.text "I'm inside a flex-item!" ]
            ]

values.name: h1
values.comment:

You can add custom block style on it, but can't turn it inline.

    title =
        BodyBuilder.h1
            [ BodyBuilder.Attributes.style [ Style.blockProperties [] ] ]
            [ Html.text "I'm inside a title!" ]

values.name: none
values.comment:
Don't create anything in the DOM. This is useful when you have a conditionnal
and are forced to return a Node.

    textOrNone : Maybe String -> NodeWithStyle msg
    textOrNone value =
        case value of
            Nothing ->
                BodyBuilder.none

            Just content ->
                BodyBuilder.text content

values.name: option
values.comment:
Generates an option in the DOM. An option is only used inside select, and
constituted of to String: the value and the content. It can also be selected, or not.

    selectElement : NodeWithStyle msg
    selectElement =
        BodyBuilder.select []
            [ BodyBuilder.option "Paris" "We're in Paris!" True
            , BodyBuilder.option "London" "We're in London!" False
            , BodyBuilder.option "Berlin" "We're in Berlin!" False
            ]

        BodyBuilder.p
            [ BodyBuilder.Attributes.style [ Style.blockProperties [] ] ]
            [ Html.text "I'm inside a paragrah!" ]

name: Color

unions.name: Color
unions.comment: Representation of colors.

unions.name: Gradient
unions.comment: Abstract representation of a color gradient.

values.name: complement
values.comment:
Produce a “complementary color”. The two colors will
accent each other. This is the same as rotating the hue by 180°.

values.name: grayscale
values.comment: Produce a gray based on the input. 0 is white, 1 is black.

values.name: greyscale
values.comment: Produce a gray based on the input. 0 is white, 1 is black.

values.name: hsl
values.comment:
Create [HSL colors](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HSL_and_HSV). This gives
you access to colors more like a color wheel, where all hues are arranged in a
circle that you specify with standard Elm angles (radians).

    red =
        hsl (degrees 0) 1 0.5

    green =
        hsl (degrees 120) 1 0.5

    blue =
        hsl (degrees 240) 1 0.5

    pastelRed =
        hsl (degrees 0) 0.7 0.7

To cycle through all colors, just cycle through degrees. The saturation level
is how vibrant the color is, like a dial between grey and bright colors. The
lightness level is a dial between white and black.

values.name: hsla
values.comment:
Create [HSL colors](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HSL_and_HSV)
with an alpha component for transparency.

values.name: linear
values.comment:
Create a linear gradient. Takes a start and end point and then a series of
“color stops” that indicate how to interpolate between the start and
end points. See [this example](http://elm-lang.org/examples/linear-gradient) for a
more visual explanation.
values.type: ( Basics.Float, Basics.Float ) -> ( Basics.Float, Basics.Float ) -> List.List ( Basics.Float, Color.Color ) -> Color.Gradient

values.name: radial
values.comment:
Create a radial gradient. First takes a start point and inner radius. Then
takes an end point and outer radius. It then takes a series of “color
stops” that indicate how to interpolate between the inner and outer
circles. See [this example](http://elm-lang.org/examples/radial-gradient) for a
more visual explanation.
values.type: ( Basics.Float, Basics.Float ) -> Basics.Float -> ( Basics.Float, Basics.Float ) -> Basics.Float -> List.List ( Basics.Float, Color.Color ) -> Color.Gradient

values.name: rgb
values.comment: Create RGB colors from numbers between 0 and 255 inclusive.

values.name: rgba
values.comment:
Create RGB colors with an alpha component for transparency.
The alpha component is specified with numbers between 0 and 1.

values.name: toHsl
values.comment: Extract the components of a color in the HSL format.
values.type: Color.Color -> { hue : Basics.Float, saturation : Basics.Float, lightness : Basics.Float, alpha : Basics.Float }

values.name: toRgb
values.comment: Extract the components of a color in the RGB format.
values.type: Color.Color -> { red : Basics.Int, green : Basics.Int, blue : Basics.Int, alpha : Basics.Float }

name: Color.Convert

values.name: colorToCssHsl
values.comment:
Converts a color to an css hsl string.

    colorToCssHsl (hsl 1 1 0.5) -- "hsl(1, 1, 0.5)"

values.name: colorToCssHsla
values.comment:
Converts a color to an css hsla string.

    colorToCssHsla (hsla 1 1 0.5 1) -- "hsla(56, 100%, 50%, 1)"

values.name: colorToCssRgb
values.comment:
Converts a color to an css rgb string.

    colorToCssRgb (rgb 255 0 0) -- "rgb(255, 0, 0)"

values.name: colorToCssRgba
values.comment:
Converts a color to an css rgba string.

    colorToCssRgba (rgba 255 0 0 0.5) -- "rgba(255, 0, 0, 0.5)"

values.name: colorToHex
values.comment:
Converts a color to a hexadecimal string.

    colorToHex (rgb  255 0 0)     -- "#ff0000"
    colorToHex (rgba 255 0 0 1.0) -- "#ff0000"
    colorToHex (rgba 255 0 0 0.5) -- "#ff0000"
    colorToHex (rgba 255 0 0 0.0) -- "#ff0000"

If you want support for colors with alpha transparency, either use `colorToCssRgba` or `colorToHexWithAlpha`.

values.name: colorToHexWithAlpha
values.comment:
Converts a color to a hexadecimal string.

If the color has alpha transparency different from 1, it will use the `#RRGGBBAA` format.
Note that the support for that is (as of March 2018) [missing](https://caniuse.com/#feat=css-rrggbbaa) on IE, Edge and some mobile browsers.
It may be better to use `colorToCssRgba`, which has excellent support.

    colorToHexWithAlpha (rgb  255 0 0)     -- "#ff0000"
    colorToHexWithAlpha (rgba 255 0 0 1.0) -- "#ff0000"
    colorToHexWithAlpha (rgba 255 0 0 0.5) -- "#ff000080"
    colorToHexWithAlpha (rgba 255 0 0 0.0) -- "#ff000000"

values.name: colorToLab
values.comment: Convert color to CIELAB- color space
values.type: Color.Color -> { l : Basics.Float, a : Basics.Float, b : Basics.Float }

values.name: hexToColor
values.comment:
Converts a string to `Maybe` of color.

    hexToColor "#ff0000" -- "Ok (RGB 255 0 0)"
    hexToColor "#f00" -- "Ok (RGB 255 0 0)"
    hexToColor "#ff000080" -- "Ok (RGBA 255 0 0 0.5)"
    hexToColor "ff0000" -- "Ok (RGB 255 0 0)"
    hexToColor "f00" -- "Ok (RGB 255 0 0)"
    hexToColor "ff000080" -- "Ok (RGBA 255 0 0 0.5)"
    hexToColor "1234" -- "Err \"Parsing hex regex failed\""

values.name: labToColor
values.comment: Convert a color in CIELAB- color space to Elm `Color`
values.type: { l : Basics.Float, a : Basics.Float, b : Basics.Float } -> Color.Color

name: Color.Interpolate

unions.name: Space
unions.comment: The color space that is used for the interpolation

values.name: interpolate
values.comment: Linear interpolation of two colors by a factor between `0` and `1`.

name: Color.Manipulate

values.name: darken
values.comment: Decrease the lightning of a color

values.name: desaturate
values.comment: Decrease the saturation of a color

values.name: fadeIn
values.comment: Increase the opacity of a color

values.name: fadeOut
values.comment: Decrease the opacity of a color

values.name: grayscale
values.comment: Convert the color to a greyscale version, aka set saturation to 0

values.name: lighten
values.comment: Increase the lightning of a color

values.name: mix
values.comment: Mixes two colors together. This is the same as calling `weightedMix` with a weight of 0.5.

values.name: rotateHue
values.comment: Change the hue of a color. The angle value must be in degrees

values.name: saturate
values.comment: Increase the saturation of a color

values.name: scaleHsl
values.comment:
Fluidly scale saturation, lightness and alpha channel.

That means that lightening an already-light color with `scaleHsl` wont change the lightness much, but lightening
a dark color by the same amount will change it more dramatically.

For example, the lightness of a color can be anywhere between 0 and 1.0. If `scaleHsl (0, 0.4, 0) color` is called,
the resulting colors lightness will be 40% of the way between its original lightness and 1.0. If
`scaleHsl (0, -0.4, 0) color` is called instead, the lightness will be 40% of the way between the original
and 0.

The values of the supplied tuple scale saturation, lightness, and opacity, respectively, and have a valid range of
-1.0 to 1.0.

This function is inspired by the Sass function [scale-color](http://sass-lang.com/documentation/Sass/Script/Functions.html#scale_color-instance_method).

values.name: scaleRgb
values.comment:
Fluidly scale red, green, blue, and alpha channels.

That means that reddening a already-red color with `scaleRgb` wont change the redness much, but reddening a color
with little or no red by the same amount will change it more dramatically.

For example, the redness of a color can be anywhere between 0 and 255. If `scaleRgb 0.4 0 0 0 color` is called,
the resulting colors redness will be 40% of the way between its original redness and 255. If
`scaleRgb -0.4 0 0 0 color` is called instead, the redness will be 40% of the way between the original
and 0.

The values of the supplied tuple scale red, green, blue, and alpha channels, respectively, and have a valid range of
-1.0 to 1.0.

This function is inspired by the Sass function [scale-color](http://sass-lang.com/documentation/Sass/Script/Functions.html#scale_color-instance_method).
values.type: Basics.Float -> Basics.Float -> Basics.Float -> Basics.Float -> Color.Color -> Color.Color

values.name: weightedMix
values.comment:
Mixes two colors together.

This function takes the average of each of the RGB components, weighted by a provided value between 0 and 1.0. The
opacity of the colors is also considered when weighting the components.

The weight specifies the amount of the first color that should be included in the returned color. For example, a weight
of 0.5 means that half the first color and half the second color should be used. A weight of 0.25 means that a quarter
of the first color and three quarters of the second color should be used.

This function uses the same algorithm as the [mix](http://sass-lang.com/documentation/Sass/Script/Functions.html#mix-instance_method) function in Sass.

name: Elegant.Background

unions.name: Angle
unions.comment: Represents an angle. Can be either radiant or degree.

unions.name: Gradient
unions.comment:
Defines a gradient, which can be either linear or radial. They are instanciated
by the corresponding functions.

unions.name: Image
unions.comment:
Represents an image in CSS. It can be an image, represented by a source url, or
a gradiant. They are instanciated by `image` (which instanciate an Image inside a
`BackgroundImage`) or by `linear` or `radial`, instanciating a gradiant.

aliases.name: Background
aliases.comment:
The `Background` record contains everything about background rendering,
including character rendering. You probably won't use it as is, but instead using
`Box.background` which automatically generate an empty `Background` record. You
can then use modifiers. I.E.

    Box.background
        [ Elegant.color Color.white
        , Background.images
            [ Background.image "/example.photo" ]
        ]
aliases.type: { color : Maybe.Maybe Color.Color, images : List.List Elegant.Background.BackgroundImage }

aliases.name: BackgroundImage
aliases.comment:
Represents a Background Image, i.e. an image in Background. Contrary to `Image`,
a `BackgroundImage` contains an image and a position. This position set the position of the image
on the background.
aliases.type: { image : Maybe.Maybe Elegant.Background.Image, position : Maybe.Maybe (Elegant.Helpers.Vector.Vector Elegant.Helpers.Shared.SizeUnit) }

aliases.name: ColorStop
aliases.comment:
Represents a CSS Color Stop, which contains a Color, and possibly a position.
This is automatically generated by `colorStop`.
aliases.type: { position : Maybe.Maybe Elegant.Helpers.Shared.SizeUnit, color : Color.Color }

aliases.name: Degree
aliases.comment: Represents a degree.
aliases.type: Basics.Float

aliases.name: Radiant
aliases.comment: Represents a radiant.
aliases.type: Basics.Float

values.name: at
values.comment: Sets a position on both a gradient and a `BackgroundImage`.
values.type: a -> { b | position : Maybe.Maybe a } -> { b | position : Maybe.Maybe a }

values.name: backgroundToCouples
values.comment:
Compiles a `Background` record to the corresponding CSS list of tuples.
Compiles only styles which are defined, ignoring `Nothing` fields.

values.name: colorStop
values.comment: Generates a CSS Color Stop from Color to use in gradients.

values.name: default
values.comment: Generates an empty `Background`.

values.name: degree
values.comment: Generates an angle in degree from Float.

values.name: gradient
values.comment: Accepts a gradient, and creates a `BackgroundImage`.

values.name: image
values.comment:
Accepts an Url, and returns a `BackgroundImage`. This image can be modified
to add a position to it.

values.name: images
values.comment:
Modify the background rendering to add photos and gradients.
It modifies the images list in `Background`.

    Background.images
        [ Background.image "/example.photo" ]

values.name: intermediateColors
values.comment:
Sets multiples intermediate colors in a gradient.
By default, a gradient is created with two colors. This can be used to add
more colors.

values.name: linear
values.comment:
Creates a linear gradient. The angle, and two colors (one for starting color,
the second for the ending color) are required, and more colors can be added in the
gradient using `intermediateColors`.

values.name: rad
values.comment: Generates an angle in radiant from Float.

values.name: radial
values.comment:
Creates a radial gradient. Two colors (one for starting color, the second
for the ending color) are required, and more colors can be added in the gradient
using `intermediateColors`.

unions.name: CornerSet
unions.comment:
Represents the possible selected corner(s).
It can be Top, TopRight, Right, BottomRight, Bottom, BottomLeft, Left, TopLeft or All.
They are created by `top`, `topRight`, `right`, `bottomRight`, `bottom`, `bottomLeft`,
`left`, `topLeft` or `all`.

aliases.name: Corner
aliases.comment:
The `Corner` record contains everything about corner radius (also called border radius in CSS).
You probably won't use it as is, but instead using `Elegant.corner`
which automatically generate an empty `Corner` record. You

name: Elegant.Display

unions.name: Alignment
unions.comment: Represents the alignment inside a block. Can be center, right, left or justify.

unions.name: DisplayBox
unions.comment:
Represents a box and contains all the style inside.
If the display is none, no style is included. Otherwise, the display
type requires the corresponding styles. I.e. if using a flex container,
then only styles applying to flex container can be used. If using a block
container, only styles applying to block can be used, and so on.

You don't use it directly, but rather generating one with the corresponding
functions, then giving it to a function which needs one. If you want to bypass
it, you can use `Display.displayBoxToCouples`, which generates the equivalent
CSS.

unions.name: InsideDisplay
unions.comment:
Represents the style from inside a display.
Can be flow, or flex (and containing flex details).

unions.name: ListStyleType
unions.comment:
Represents the type of the list style.
Can be none, disc, circle, square, decimal or georgian.

unions.name: OutsideDisplay
unions.comment:
Represents the style from outside the display.
Can be inline, block, or flex-item.

unions.name: TextOverflow
unions.comment:
Represents the text-overflow.
Can be ellipsis.

values.name: perspective
values.comment:
Change the perspective of a scene. It represents the distance between the
z=0 plane and the user in order to give a 3D-positioned element some
perspective. Each 3D element with z>0 becomes larger; each 3D-element with z<0
becomes smaller. The strength of the effect is determined by the value of this
property.

values.name: perspectiveOrigin
values.comment:
Define the origin of the perspective of a scene. It represents the position
at which the viewer is looking. It is used as the vanishing point by the
perspective property.

values.comment: in a (css) 3d rendered scene, we hide back facing elements.

name: Elegant.Typography

unions.name: Capitalization
unions.comment:
Represents the possible transformations of the text.
It can be Uppercase, Lowercase, or Capitalize. They are created by `uppercase`,
`lowercase` and `capitalize`.

unions.name: CustomFontFamily
unions.comment:
Represents the font family used to render characters.
It can be a system or a custom type. They are created by `systemFont` and `customFont`.

unions.name: Decoration
unions.comment:
Represents the possible decorations of the text.
It can be None, Underline or LineThrough. They are created by `noDecoration`,
`underline` and `lineThrough`.

unions.name: FontFamily
unions.comment:
Represents the possible fontFamily of the characters.
It can be Inherited from the parent, or customized.

unions.name: FontTilt
unions.comment:
Represents the possible tilting of the characters.
It can be Normal, Italic, or Oblique. They are created by `uppercase`,
`lowercase` and `capitalize`.

unions.name: Normal
unions.comment: Value representing the 'normal' value in `line-height`.

unions.name: WhiteSpaceWrap
unions.comment:
Represents the whitespaces management in the text.
It can be NoWrap, and created by `whiteSpaceNoWrap`.

aliases.name: Typography
aliases.comment:
The `Typography` record contains everything about fonts rendering,
including character rendering. You probably won't use it as is, but instead using
`Box.typography` which automatically generate an empty `Typography` record. You
can then use modifiers. I.E.

    Box.typography
        [ Typography.color Color.white
        , Typography.italic
        ]
aliases.type: { capitalization : Maybe.Maybe Elegant.Typography.Capitalization, decoration : Maybe.Maybe Elegant.Typography.Decoration, color : Maybe.Maybe Color.Color, whiteSpaceWrap : Maybe.Maybe Elegant.Typography.WhiteSpaceWrap, userSelect : Maybe.Maybe Elegant.Typography.UserSelect, lineHeight : Maybe.Maybe (Either.Either Elegant.Helpers.Shared.SizeUnit Elegant.Typography.Normal), weight : Maybe.Maybe Basics.Int, tilt : Maybe.Maybe Elegant.Typography.FontTilt, size : Maybe.Maybe Elegant.Helpers.Shared.SizeUnit, family : Maybe.Maybe Elegant.Typography.FontFamily, letterSpacing : Maybe.Maybe Elegant.Helpers.Shared.SizeUnit }

aliases.name: UserSelect
aliases.comment:
Represents the interaction with the user. If set to `True`, the user
can interact with the text, i.e. can select it, copy and paste. If set to
`False`, nothing can be done.
aliases.type: Basics.Bool

values.name: capitalize
values.comment:
Capitalize the first letter in the text.
'just an example' is transformed in 'Just an example'.

values.name: color
values.comment: Set the color of the typography

values.name: customFont
values.comment: Gives a custom font.

values.name: default
values.comment:
Generate an empty `Typography` record, with every field equal to Nothing.
You are free to use it as you wish, but it is instanciated automatically by `Box.typography`.

values.name: fontFamily
values.comment:
Set the font family to the desired fonts. All fonts will be tried one by one
until one is found either on the browser or user's OS. It is possible to use both
system and custom fonts.

values.name: fontFamilyInherit
values.comment: Inherits the font from the parents. It is the default behavior of fontFamily.

values.name: fontFamilySansSerif
values.comment:
Standard Sans Serif font family.
Inspired from <https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2015/11/using-system-ui-fonts-practical-guide/>

values.name: italic
values.comment: Renders the characters as italic.

values.name: letterSpacing
values.comment: Set the letter spacing of the typography.

values.name: lineHeight
values.comment: Set the lineHeight to the desired value. Can be px, pt, vh, em or rem.

values.name: lineHeightNormal
values.comment:
Set the lineHeight property to respect the space defined by the User Agent of
the user's browser. It usually is 1.2em, but can vary.

values.name: lineThrough
values.comment: Print a line through the text.

values.name: lowercase
values.comment:
Turn the entire text in lowercase.
'JuST an ExAMPle' is transformed in 'just an example'.

values.name: noDecoration
values.comment: Remove every decoration (underline or lineThrough) on the text.

values.name: oblique
values.comment: Renders the characters as oblique.

values.name: size
values.comment:
Set the size of the characters to the desired value.
Can be px, pt, vh, em or rem.

values.name: systemFont
values.comment: Gives a system font.

values.name: tiltNormal
values.comment: Cancels any tilting of the characters.

values.name: typographyToCouples
values.comment:
Compiles a `Typography` record to the corresponding CSS list of tuples.
Compiles only styles which are defined, ignoring `Nothing` fields.

values.name: underline
values.comment: Underline the text.

values.name: uppercase
values.comment:
Turn the entire text in uppercase.
'JuST an ExAMPle' is transformed in 'JUSTANEXAMPLE'.

values.name: userSelect
values.comment: Allow or disallow user to interact with the text, i.e. select, copy, etc.

values.name: weight
values.comment:
Changes the weight of the characters.
Value is defined between 100 and 900 and default weight is equal to 400.

values.name: whiteSpaceNoWrap
values.comment: Cancel the wrapping of the text on whitespaces. It forces text to stay on one line.
